docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Scott M. Riemer (letter, March 18) suggests that disputes involving health care coverage be resolved -- without lawyers -- in small claims court. However, litigants who represent themselves are at a monumental disadvantage. To establish a claim, one usually presents medical bills and introduces medical articles from newspapers, magazines and medical journals. The defendant often presents a physician and other ''expert testimony.''

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of her 65 years, Verna Pugh never went to doctors. But inexplicably, she has lost 44 of her 169 pounds in just a few months, and that has brought her to the Meharry Medical College's health clinic here on a winter afternoon. Larry Hooten, 44, is recovering from bypass surgery and still struggling to change his diet and lose weight. ''I have been dealing with hypertension for 20 years,'' he said.

headline.main: Nashville Clinic Offers Case Study of Chronic Gap in Black and White Health

docs.abstract: Gap between health of whites and blacks remains one of nation's most vexing health care problems; Centers for Disease Control, which recently reported first decline in cancer cases since 1930's, noted that black men, alone among population groups, had rising rates of cancer between 1990 and 1995 and that black women contracted more cases of breast cancer; African-Americans contract most major diseases sooner than whites and die six or seven years sooner; stubborn black-white gaps are getting even bigger for diabetes, maternal mortality, asthma and several forms of cancer; doctors at Meharry Medical College in Nashville, a center of research on black health, blame culture of poverty, tainted by racism; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislative leaders said today that they hoped to vote next week on a bill to reduce automobile insurance rates, but they conceded that they still had no idea what the bill would say. A bipartisan committee of 12 legislators has been struggling since November to devise a plan to reduce rates in New Jersey, which are higher than in any other state. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman almost lost the gubernatorial race last fall in large part because of widespread anger about auto insurance. After a narrow victory over her Democratic opponent, James E. McGreevey, she directed lawmakers to pass a bill reducing rates by March 31.

docs.lead_paragraph: Completing a transformation that began when she quit the Republican Party last year, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross announced today that she would seek to unseat Gov. George E. Pataki, her one-time running mate. She repeatedly urged voters to make her the state's first female governor. Taking the stage to the brassy thump of prerecorded military marches, Ms. McCaughey Ross assailed Mr. Pataki and her former political benefactor, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, presenting her candidacy as a break from politics as usual. Now a Democrat, Ms. McCaughey Ross said she would campaign against abuses by health maintenance organizations and address deep economic difficulties that she said were turning New York into a ''Charles Dickens tale of two economies.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Like the more than three million other French workers who cannot find a job, Yves Hell is angry. He lost his job as a clerk in Marseilles in December, and now, at age 35, he has had to give up his small apartment there and move in with his retired parents. What he is angry about is not so much the difficult job market or being let go as the unexpected inability of the vaunted French welfare system to provide him with a decent standard of living.

headline.main: French Jobless Find the World Is Harsher

docs.abstract: First of two articles, Help Unwanted, on unemployment in France and the pressure on Government to reverse the escalation in jobless benefits; pattern of worker entitlement, protest and Government capitulation is deep-rooted in France and has swollen welfare state into one of most comprehensive and costly in Europe, with much of the burden borne by employers; employers say payroll taxes and benefits are main reasons why the are not creating jobs; French economy is expected to post healthy 3 percent gain in 1998, but it will not produce many new jobs; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today firmly rejected the current Republican budget proposal, declaring that it ''shortchanges our nation's future'' by eliminating nearly all of his planned Federal programs for education, job training and child care. Employing sharply partisan language and speaking to a cheering crowd of union members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Clinton set out on a collision course with the Republican-controlled Congress over taxing and spending at a time when the nation will have its first projected surplus in 30 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today proposed a Republican fiscal blueprint for next year that rejects nearly all of President Clinton's calls for increased domestic spending but provides smaller tax cuts than sought by many Republicans. The proposal from Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, is the first detailed Republican budget plan this year and appeared likely to be adopted more or less intact by the committee this week over Democratic opposition. If approved by the full Senate, it would serve as the chamber's broad tax and spending guideline as it confronted the first Federal budget surpluses in a generation and began grappling with the long-term financial crises facing Social Security and Medicare.

headline.main: G.O.P. FISCAL PLAN REJECTS PROGRAMS SOUGHT BY CLINTON

docs.abstract: Senate Budget Committee chmn Pete V Domenici proposes Republican fiscal blueprint for next year that rejects nearly all of Pres Clinton's calls for increased domestic spending but provides smaller tax cuts than sought by many Republicans; proposal is first detailed Republican budget plan this year and appears likely to be adopted by committee over Democratic opposition; plan calls for Federal spending of $1.73 trillion, increase of 3.6 percent over 1998, but turns aside Administration's proposals for new education, child care and health care initiatives; it provides for tax cuts worth $30 billion over five years, and it goes along with Administration's insistence that any budget surpluses be set aside until nation agrees on way to shore up Social Security; one of Domenici proposal's main features is earmarking of any proceeds from legislated settlement with tobacco industry over illnesses caused by smoking to help Medicare; photo (M)
